# Draft:Ocean Exploration Trust

Ocean Exploration Trust (OET) is a nonprofit organization dedicated to deep-sea exploration, scientific research, and public engagement. It was founded in 2008 by oceanographer Robert Ballard, best known for discovering the wreck of the RMS Titanic in 1985.
Mission
OET’s mission is to explore the ocean using advanced technologies and to share discoveries with scientists, educators, and the public in real time. The organization promotes STEM education and supports collaborative research in marine geology, biology, chemistry, and archaeology.
E/V Nautilus
OET operates the Exploration Vessel Nautilus (E/V Nautilus), a 68-meter research ship equipped with remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) including Hercules and Argus. The vessel conducts expeditions in the Pacific, Atlantic, and Caribbean, often in partnership with NOAA, NASA, and academic institutions.
Programs
* Nautilus Live – A 24/7 livestream of deep-sea dives, available at [nautiluslive.org](https://nautiluslive.org)
* Science & Engineering Internship Program – Offers hands-on experience for students and early-career researchers
* Science Communication Fellowship – Trains educators and communicators to engage the public in ocean science
Partnerships
OET collaborates with:
* National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)
* National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA)
* Schmidt Ocean Institute
* Various universities and marine research centers
Notable expeditions
OET has conducted expeditions to:
* Hydrothermal vent fields
* Submarine volcanoes
* Shipwrecks and cultural heritage sites
* Deep coral ecosystems
